title: Are NFL Running Backs Being Under-Payed?
text:
On September 9, 2024, Dak Prescott became the highest-paid player in the National Football League, signing a four-year, $240 million contract extension with the Dallas Cowboys. His contract gave him an $80 million signing bonus and carries an annual value of $60 million per season. In other words, he is making $164,383.56 per day, $6,849.32 per hour, $114.16 per minute, or $1.90 per second.
As crazy as those numbers are, they will only continue to grow for his peers at a steady pace over the coming years, as the quarterback position market value only continues to grow. The market for NFL running backs, contrary to other positions like wide receiver, quarterback, and edge rusher, has been rather stagnant.
There are several reasons why the running back market isn’t growing. First, the position is very physically demanding, which shortens the chances of being able to play for many years. This leads teams to be hesitant to give running backs large contracts, especially in an era where it seems as though they can be quickly replaced with cheaper and younger options. Many teams have also switched to a running back-by-committee approach instead of leaning on one guy.
It can be hard to convince a general manager to offer running backs large, long-term contracts when the position is full of inconsistencies. Even some of the best running backs in the NFL over the last five years have struggled to stay consistent.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(nflreadr)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(nflverse)
library(nflreadr)




Code
pbp_data <- load_pbp(seasons = 2010:2023) 




Code
roster_data <- nflreadr::load_rosters(seasons = 2010:2023)




Code
players <- c("D.Henry", "C.McCaffrey", "S.Barkley", "J.Taylor", "A.Kamara")
seasons <- 2019:2023




Code
offense_data <- load_player_stats(stat_type = "offense", seasons = seasons)




Code
rushing_data <- offense_data |>
  filter(player_name %in% players, !is.na(rushing_yards)) |>
  select(season, player_name, rushing_yards) |>
  group_by(season, player_name) |>
  summarize(total_rushing_yards = sum(rushing_yards, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")




Code
ggplot(rushing_data, aes(x = season, y = total_rushing_yards, color = player_name, group = player_name)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "The statistical career of an NFL running back is not an even road",
    subtitle = "Christian McCaffrey and Saquon Barkley missed 23 of 33 games from 2020-2021",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Total Rushing Yards",
    color = "Players",
    caption = "By: Zach Wordekemper | Source:nflverse"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seasons) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(size = 14),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10, hjust = 0.5), 
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )









Obviously, Christian McCaffrey had a great season in 2023. Consequentially, he is the highest-paid running back in the league, making over $15 million per year. However, he is once again facing injury problems in 2024 after he missed the first eight weeks of the season. With a history of injuries, was what he did in 2023 impressive enough to still warrant being the highest paid running back in the league? Well, let’s look at how the ten highest paid running backs in 2023 compared.


Code
highest_paid_rbs <- c("C.McCaffrey", "A.Kamara", "D.Henry", "N.Chubb", "A.Jones", "S.Barkley", "T.Pollard", "J.Jacobs", "J.Conner", "M.Sanders")




Code
pbp_2023 <- load_pbp(2023)




Code
rb_yards <- pbp_2023 |>
  filter(play_type == "run" & rusher_player_name %in% highest_paid_rbs) |>
  group_by(rusher_player_name) |>
  summarize(
    total_rushing_yards = sum(rushing_yards, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(total_rushing_yards))




Code
ggplot(rb_yards, aes(x = reorder(rusher_player_name, -total_rushing_yards), y = total_rushing_yards, fill = rusher_player_name)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(
    title = "Christian McCaffrey is in a league of his own",
    subtitle = "The rest of the top ten lag behind",
    x = "Top 10 Highest Paid Running Backs",
    y = "Rushing Yards in 2023",
    caption = "By: Zach Wordekemper | Source: nflverse",
    fill = "Player"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    legend.position = "none"
  )









Well, you could argue that Christian McCaffrey is worth the money. However, it is also worth acknowledging that Nick Chubb missed most of the 2023 season after suffering a season-ending injury in week two. Showing another example of one of the best running backs in the league going down to an unpredictable injury, which heavily hurts the teams investing in them.
An important question to be asked, is does having one of the highest-paid running backs in the league contribute to more team scoring? By simple reasoning, one could assume that if a team is paying a running back a lot of money, he is a good player who can contribute a lot of scoring for the offense. I mean, after all, winning games just means scoring more than the other team.


Code
library(dplyr)
library(gt)
library(nflreadr)




Code
pbp_2023 <- pbp_2023 |>
  mutate(
    points = case_when(
      play_type == "pass" & !is.na(td_team) ~ 6,  
      play_type == "run" & !is.na(td_team) ~ 6,    
      play_type == "field_goal" ~ 3,              
      TRUE ~ 0                                    
    )
  )




Code
team_stats_2023 <- pbp_2023 |>
  filter(!is.na(posteam), points > 0) |>
  group_by(posteam) |>
  summarize(
    TotalPoints = sum(points, na.rm = TRUE),
    GamesPlayed = n_distinct(game_id),
    AvgPoints = TotalPoints / GamesPlayed
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(AvgPoints))




Code
top10_offenses <- team_stats_2023 |>
  slice_max(AvgPoints, n = 10)




Code
top10_offenses |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    posteam = "Team",
    TotalPoints = "Total Points Scored",
    AvgPoints = "Points Per Game",
    GamesPlayed = "Games Played"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Three of the top ten offenses had one of the most expensive running backs",
    subtitle = "Christian McCaffrey and San Francisco scored a lot"
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_fill(color = "lightblue"),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = everything(),
      rows = posteam %in% c("DAL", "SF", "CLE")
    )
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Zach Wordekemper  |  **Source:** nflverse")
  )

Based on the chart, one could make the assumption that having a highly payed running back is not always the most effective equation for a good offense. Obviously, if you are lucky enough to have a really good quarterback, it is important to get them paid on a long-term contract. If you have an elite wide receiver, it is probably safer to invest in them, as the position is more durable than running backs. It is hard to argue for the case of paying running backs expensive, long-term contracts, as the position can be so inconsistent, and doesn’t really have a direct correlation with scoring a lot of points. Unless of course, you have an anomaly like Christian McCaffrey. Who, in his case, might just be worth the money.
